.T: Neuromuscular function: comparison of symptomatic and asymptomatic polio subjects to control subjects.
.W: The purpose of this study was to determine if there were any differences between symptomatic and asymptomatic polio survivors by history of acute poliomyelitis illness, electromyographic evidence of terminal motor unit reorganization, and neuromuscular function of the quadriceps femoris muscle. .W: Exercise as a treatment for muscular dystrophy is controversial. .T: Postpartum femoral neuropathy: relic of an earlier era?
.W: Femoral neuropathy after childbirth is rarely encountered today, although around 1900 an incidence of up to 4.7% was found. A case of postpartum unilateral femoral neuropathy in a 29-year-old primigravida is described. The patient's labor was complicated by poor progression, a prolonged second stage (three hours), and midforceps delivery. The patient received both epidural anesthesia (requiring catheter manipulation) and spinal anesthesia. Total time in the dorsal lithotomy position was four hours; total duration of labor was 27 hours. After delivery, the patient experienced buckling at the right knee and numbness down the leg anteriorly. The electromyogram at one month was consistent with an acute femoral neuropathy. These results indicate that skin thickness and extensibility are the most useful parameters in the study of the progression of LS and PSS.
